title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: I had thrown up my "yob," had saved a little money and was now ready to purchase a ticket for the old country. Steamship offices in lower Broadway and along Bowling Green are numerous, in fact that is where the majority of them are located, but the vessels themselves are berthed in piers along the Hudson River. In the vicinity of Bowling Green are situated the offices of steamship lines that sell tickets for London direct, Liverpool, Hull, Bristol, Southampton, Dublin, Cork^ Belfast, Fishguard^ Rotterdam, Amsterdam and other dams;

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: In 1871, when the engagement of the Princess Louise was an- nounced to an old Scotchman, he remarked to his com- panion, " Aye, mon, but the Queen's a lucky chiel to catch sic a mon as Macallum More for her daughter." We left Inveraray on a four-in-hand coach, drove through " Argyll's Bowling Green," a range of very rugged and precipitous mountains, and a splendid specimen of the Highlands, thence into Glencoe, a wild region, which con- tains the grandest, gloomiest and most awful scenery I have yet witnessed. It was a fearful pull for the horses to the top of one of the hills; on the summit is a small monument called "The Rest, and be Thankful."

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: They made our stay most agreeable. Mr. Murray took us to the Bowling Green in the evening, and many of our party saw the game for the first time. Great excitement prevails when the sides are evenly matched.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: They made our stay most agreeable. Mr. Murray took us to the Bowling Green in the evening, and many of our party saw the game for the first time. Great excitement prevails when the sides are evenly matched.

title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: It was a red hot morning in the month of August when I boarded a street car and rode down Broadway toward Bowling Green to see what kind of announcements there were in the steamship offices as regards a trip to Europe. I had thrown up my "yob," had saved a little money and was now ready to purchase a ticket for the old country.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: The originator and promoter of the scheme was Cyrus W. Field, of Atlantic cable fame. For five miles from Bowling Green northwards the trains of this novel line dash along in mid air. The carriages and way-stations are got up regardless of expense in the way of luxurious furnishings.

title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: Steamship offices in lower Broadway and along Bowling Green are numerous, in fact that is where the majority of them are located, but the vessels themselves are berthed in piers along the Hudson River. In the vicinity of Bowling Green are situated the offices of steamship lines that sell tickets for London direct, Liverpool, Hull, Bristol, Southampton, Dublin, Cork^ Belfast, Fishguard^ Rotterdam, Amsterdam and other dams;

title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: Having a letter from Superintendent Charles Graham, of Scranton, to Mr. Andrew Swan, I called upon the Swans and remained with them all night, and on the following morning Mr. A. Swan, Jr., went with me for a walk. We ascended a high hill near the city, where we could look down upon Greenock and the harbor, the winding Clyde and the great maze of mountain peaks beyond, which is known as the " Duke of Argyle's Bowling Green."

title: The life of Samuel Johnson, LL. D. :
author: Boswell, James
snippet: Mr. Crost very properly guards us against supposing that Young \ya3 a gloomy man ; and mentions, that ** his parish was indebted to the good humour of the authour of the * Night Thoughts ' for an Assembly and a Bowling Green." A letter from a noble foreigner is quoted, in which he is said to have been *' very pleasant in conversation."
